Recommendations for the Remediation of Bots in ISP Networks
Abstract
contents.ja: 抽象

contents.text: This document contains recommendations on how Internet Service Providers can use various remediation techniques to manage the effects of malicious bot infestations on computers used by their subscribers. Internet users with infected computers are exposed to risks such as loss of personal data and increased susceptibility to online fraud. Such computers can also become inadvertent participants in or components of an online crime network, spam network, and/or phishing network as well as be used as a part of a distributed denial-of-service attack. Mitigating the effects of and remediating the installations of malicious bots will make it more difficult for botnets to operate and could reduce the level of online crime on the Internet in general and/or on a particular Internet Service Provider's network.
contents.ja: この文書は、インターネット・サービス・プロバイダは、加入者が使用するコンピュータ上で悪質なボット蔓延の影響を管理するために、様々な修復技術を使用することができる方法に関する推奨事項が含まれています。感染したコンピュータとインターネットユーザーは、個人データの紛失などのリスクにさらされ、オンライン詐欺に対する感受性を増加させています。このようなコンピュータは、不注意の参加者やオンライン犯罪ネットワーク、スパムネットワークのコンポーネント、および/またはフィッシングネットワークになることができますだけでなく、分散型サービス拒否攻撃の一部として使用されます。影響を緩和し、悪質なボットのインストールを修復することがより困難ボットネットを動作させるために作るだろうと一般的におよび/または特定のインターネットサービスプロバイダのネットワーク上でインターネット上のオンライン犯罪のレベルを低下させる可能性があります。

contents.text: 1.1. Key Terminology
contents.ja: 1.1. 主な用語

contents.text: This section defines the key terms used in this document.

contents.text: 1.1.1. Malicious Bots, or Bots
contents.ja: 1.1.1. 悪意のあるボット、またはボット

contents.text: A malicious or potentially malicious bot (derived from the word "robot", hereafter simply referred to as a "bot") refers to a program that is installed on a system in order to enable that system to automatically (or semi-automatically) perform a task or set of tasks typically under the command and control of a remote administrator, or "bot master". Bots are also known as "zombies". Such bots may have been installed surreptitiously, without the user's full understanding of what the bot will do once installed, unknowingly as part of another software installation, under false pretenses, and/or in a variety of other possible ways.
contents.ja: （単語「ロボット」に由来する、以下、単に「ボット」と呼ばれる）、悪意のあるまたは悪意のあるボットは自動的に（または半自動的に）実行するようにそのシステムを有効にするために、システムにインストールされたプログラムを指しタスクまたは一般的にリモート管理者のコマンドと制御の下で、タスクのセット、または「ボットマスター」。ボットは、「ゾンビ」として知られています。このようなボットは、ボットがかつて知らないうちに別のソフトウェアのインストールの一部として、偽っ下、および/または他の可能なさまざまな方法で、インストール何をするかをユーザが完全に理解せずに、ひそかにインストールされている可能性があります。

contents.text: It is important to note that there are "good" bots. Such good bots are often found interacting with a computing resource in environments such as gaming and Internet Relay Chat (IRC) [RFC1459], where a continual, interactive presence can be a requirement for participating in the games. Since such good bots are performing useful, lawful, and non-disruptive functions, there is no reason for a provider to monitor for their presence and/or alert users to their presence.
contents.ja: 「良い」ボットがあることに注意することが重要です。良好なボットは、多くの場合、継続的な、インタラクティブ存在がゲームに参加するための要件であることができるゲーム、インターネットリレーチャット（IRC）[RFC1459]などの環境において、コンピューティングリソースと相互作用が見出されています。このような良いボットは、便利な合法的、かつ無停止機能を実行しているので、彼らの存在のために彼らの存在および/または警告のユーザーのために監視するためのプロバイダのための理由はありません。

contents.text: While there may be good, or harmless bots, for the purposes of this document, all mention of bots shall assume that the bots involved are malicious or potentially malicious in nature. Such malicious bots shall generally be assumed to have been deployed without the permission or conscious understanding of a particular Internet user. Thus, without a user's knowledge, bots may transform the user's computing device into a platform from which malicious activities can be conducted. In addition, included explicitly in this category are potentially malicious bots, which may initially appear neutral but may simply be waiting for remote instructions to transform and/or otherwise begin engaging in malicious behavior. In general, installation of a malicious bot without user knowledge and consent is considered in most regions to be unlawful, and the activities of malicious bots typically involve unlawful or other maliciously disruptive activities.
contents.ja: 良い、または無害なボットがあるかもしれませんが、このドキュメントの目的のために、ボットのすべての言及は関与ボットは、自然の中で悪意のあるまたは潜在的な不正であることを前提としなければなりません。このような悪質なボットは、一般的に、特定のインターネットユーザーの許可または意識的に理解せずに配備されていると想定されなければなりません。このように、ユーザーの知識がなくても、ボットは、悪意のある活動を行うことができ、そこからプラットフォームにユーザのコンピューティングデバイスを変換することができます。また、明示的にこのカテゴリには、最初は中立表示されることがあり、潜在的に悪質なボット、ですが、単純に変換し、および/またはその他の悪質な行動に従事開始するために、遠隔指示を待っているかもしれ含まれています。一般的には、ユーザーの知識や同意なしに悪質なボットのインストールは、違法なことをほとんどの地域では考慮されており、悪質なボットの活動は、一般的に違法な目的またはその他の悪意をもって破壊活動を伴います。

contents.text: 1.1.2. Bot Networks, or Botnets
contents.ja: 1.1.2. ボットネットワーク、またはボットネット

contents.text: A "bot network", or "botnet", is defined as a concerted network of bots capable of acting on instructions generated remotely. The malicious activities are either focused on the information on the local machine or acting to provide services for remote machines. Bots are highly customizable so they can be programmed to do many things. The major malicious activities include but are not limited to identity theft, spam, spim (spam over Instant Messaging (IM)), spit (spam over Internet telephony), email address harvesting, distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, key-logging, fraudulent DNS pharming (redirection), hosting proxy services, fast flux (see Section 1.1.5) hosting, hosting of illegal content, use in man-in-the-middle attacks, and click fraud.
contents.ja: 「ボットネットワーク」、または「ボットネット」は、遠隔で生成された命令に作用することが可能なロボットの協調ネットワークとして定義されます。悪質な活動は、ローカルマシン上の情報に焦点を当て、またはリモートマシンのサービスを提供するために行動しています。ボットは、高度にカスタマイズされているので、彼らは多くのことを行うようにプログラムすることができます。主要な悪質な活動としては、個人情報の盗難、スパム、スピム（インスタントメッセージングを超えるスパム（IM））、串（インターネット電話経由のスパム）、電子メールアドレスの収穫、分散型サービス拒否（DDoS）攻撃、キーに限定されないがman-in-the-middle攻撃に使用し、違法なコンテンツのホスティング、ホスティング（セクション1.1.5を参照）、および詐欺をクリックし-logging、詐欺のDNSファーミング（リダイレクト）、プロキシサービスをホスティング、高速なフラックス。

contents.text: Infection vectors (infection pathways) include un-patched operating systems, software vulnerabilities (which include so-called zero-day vulnerabilities where no patch yet exists), weak/non-existent passwords, malicious web sites, un-patched browsers, malware, vulnerable helper applications, inherently insecure protocols, protocols implemented without security features switched on, and social engineering techniques to gain access to the user's computer. The detection and destruction of bots is an ongoing issue and also a constant battle between the Internet security community and network security engineers on the one hand and bot developers on the other.

contents.text: Initially, some bots used IRC to communicate but were easy to shut down if the command and control server was identified and deactivated. Newer command and control methods have evolved, such that those currently employed by bot masters make them much more resistant to deactivation. With the introduction of peer-to-peer (P2P) architectures and associated protocols, the use of HTTP and other resilient communication protocols, and the widespread adoption of encryption, bots are considerably more difficult to identify and isolate from typical network usage. As a result, increased reliance is being placed on anomaly detection and behavioral analysis, both locally and remotely, to identify bots.

contents.text: 1.1.3. Host

As used in the context of this document, the host or computer of an end user is intended to refer to a computing device that connects to the Internet. This encompasses devices used by Internet users such as personal computers (including laptops, desktops, and netbooks), mobile phones, smart phones, home gateway devices, and other end user computing devices that are connected or can connect to the public Internet and/or private IP networks.

contents.text: Increasingly, other household systems and devices contain embedded hosts that are connected to or can connect to the public Internet and/or private IP networks. However, these devices may not be under interactive control of the Internet user, such as may be the case with various smart home and smart grid devices.

contents.text: 1.1.4. Malware
contents.ja: 1.1.4. マルウェア

contents.text: Malware is short for "malicious software". In this case, malicious bots are considered a subset of malware. Other forms of malware could include viruses and other similar types of software. Internet users can sometimes cause their hosts to be infected with malware, which may include a bot or cause a bot to install itself, via inadvertently accessing a specific web site, downloading a file, or other activities.

contents.text: In other cases, Internet-connected hosts may become infected with malware through externally initiated malicious activities such as the exploitation of vulnerabilities or the brute force guessing of access credentials.

contents.text: 1.1.5. Fast Flux
contents.ja: 1.1.5. 高速フラックス

contents.text: Domain Name System (DNS) fast fluxing occurs when a domain is bound in DNS using A records to multiple IP addresses, each of which has a very short Time-to-Live (TTL) value associated with it. This means that the domain resolves to varying IP addresses over a short period of time.

contents.text: DNS fast flux is typically used in conjunction with proxies that are normally run on compromised user hosts. These proxies route the web requests to the real host, which serves the data being sought. The effect of this is to make the detection of the real host much more difficult and to ensure that the backend or hidden site remains up for as long as possible.

contents.text: 2. Problem Statement
contents.ja: 2.問題文

contents.text: Hosts used by Internet users, which in this case are customers of an Internet Service Provider (ISP), can be infected with malware that may contain and/or install one or more bots on a host. They can present a major problem for an ISP for a number of reasons (not to mention, of course, the problems created for users). First, these bots can be used to send spam, in some cases very large volumes of spam [Spamalytics]. This spam can result in extra cost for the ISPs in terms of wasted network, server, and/or personnel resources, among many other potential costs and side effects. Such spam can also negatively affect the reputation of the ISP, their customers, and the email reputation of the IP address space used by the ISP (often referred to simply as "IP reputation"). A further potential complication is that IP space compromised by bad reputation may continue to carry this bad reputation even when used for entirely innocent purposes following reassignment of that IP space.
contents.ja: この場合には、インターネットサービスプロバイダ（ISP）の顧客であるインターネットユーザーが使用するホストは、含まれているおよび/またはホスト上の1つのまたはそれ以上のボットをインストールすることがマルウェアに感染することができます。彼らはいくつかの理由で（当然のではないに言及し、ユーザーのために作成された問題）のためのISPのために大きな問題を提示することができます。まず、これらのボットは、いくつかのケースでは、[Spamalytics]スパムの非常に大量のスパムを送信するために使用することができます。このスパムは、他の多くの潜在的なコストと副作用の間で無駄なネットワーク、サーバ、および/または人的資源の面でのISPのための余分なコストが発生することができます。このようなスパムも否定ISP、顧客、およびISPによって使用されるIPアドレス空間の電子メールの評判の評判に影響を与えることができます（多くの場合、単に「IPレピュテーション」と呼びます）。さらに潜在的な合併症は、悪い評判によって損なわIP空間はそのIP空間の再割り当て以下の完全無実の目的のために使用した場合であっても、この悪い評判を運ぶために続けることです。

contents.text: In addition, these bots can act as platforms for directing, participating in, or otherwise conducting attacks on critical Internet infrastructure [Threat-Report]. Bots are frequently used as part of coordinated DDoS attacks for criminal, political, or other motivations [Gh0st][Dragon][DDoS]. For example, bots have been used to attack Internet resources and infrastructure ranging from web sites to email servers and DNS servers, as well as the critical Internet infrastructure of entire countries [Estonia][Combat-Zone]. Motivations for such coordinated DDoS attacks can range from criminal extortion attempts through to online protesting and nationalistic fervor [Whiz-Kid]. DDoS attacks may also be motivated by simple personal vendettas or by persons simply seeking a cheap thrill at the expense of others.

contents.text: There is good evidence to suggest that bots are being used in the corporate environment for purposes of corporate espionage including the exfiltration of corporate financial data and intellectual property. This also extends to the possibility of bots being used for state-sponsored purposes such as espionage.

contents.text: While any computing device can be infected with bots, the majority of bot infections affect the personal computers used by Internet end users. As a result of the role of ISPs in providing IP connectivity, among many other services, to Internet users, these ISPs are in a unique position to be able to attempt to detect and observe botnets operating in their networks. Furthermore, ISPs may also be in a unique position to be able to notify their customers of actual, potential, or likely infection by bots or other infection.
contents.ja: 任意のコンピューティングデバイスは、ボットに感染したことができますが、ボット感染の大半は、インターネットのエンドユーザーが使用するパーソナルコンピュータに影響を与えます。インターネットユーザーに、他の多くのサービスの中で、IP接続を提供するISPでの役割の結果として、これらのISPは自社のネットワークで動作してボットネットを検出し、観察しようとすることができるようにするユニークな立場にあります。さらに、ISPはまた、ボットやその他の感染により、実際の潜在的な、または可能性の高い感染症の顧客に通知することができるように独自の地位にあってもよいです。

contents.text: From the perspective of end users, being notified that they may have an infected computer on their network is important information. Once they know this, they can take steps to remove the bots, resolve any problems that may stem from the bot infection, and protect themselves against future threats. It is important to notify users that they may be infected with a bot because bots can consume vast amounts of local computing and network resources, enable theft of personal information (including personal financial information), enable the host to be used for criminal activities (that may result in the Internet user being legally culpable), and destroy or leave the host in an unrecoverable state via "kill switch" bot technologies.
contents.ja: エンドユーザーの観点から、彼らのネットワークは重要な情報である上、彼らが感染したコンピュータを有することができることが通知されています。彼らはこのことを知ったら、彼らは、ボットを削除ボット感染から生じる可能性のある問題を解決し、将来の脅威から身を守るための手順を取ることができます。それは、ボットは、ローカルコンピューティングとネットワーク資源の膨大な量を消費することができますので、彼らはボットに感染する可能性があり、ユーザーに通知する（個人の財務情報を含む）個人情報の盗難を可能にする、ホストを有効にすることが重要である（その犯罪行為のために使用されます）インターネット利用者が法的過失であることになり、そして「スイッチを殺す」ボット技術を介して、回復不能な状態でホストを破壊するか、残すことができます。

contents.text: As a result, the intent of this document is to provide guidance to ISPs and other organizations for the remediation of hosts infected with bots, so as to reduce the size of botnets and minimize the potential harm that bots can inflict upon Internet infrastructure in general as well as on individual Internet users. Efforts by ISPs and other organizations can, over time, reduce the pool of hosts infected with bots on the Internet, which in turn could result in smaller botnets with less capability for disruption.

contents.text: The potential mitigation of bots is accomplished through a process of detection, notification to Internet users, and remediation of bot infections with a variety of tools, as described later in this document.

contents.text: 3. Important Notice of Limitations and Scope
contents.ja: 3.制限事項の重要なお知らせと範囲

contents.text: The techniques described in this document in no way guarantee the remediation of all bots. Bot removal is potentially a task requiring specialized knowledge, skills, and tools; it may be beyond the ability of average users. Attempts at bot removal may frequently be unsuccessful, or only partially successful, leaving the user's system in an unstable and unsatisfactory state or even in a state where it is still infected. Attempts at bot removal can result in side effects ranging from a loss of data to partial or complete loss of system usability.

However, the introduction of persistent memory-based malware may mean that, in some cases, this may not be enough and may prove to be more than any end user can be reasonably expected to resolve [BIOS]. Experienced users would have to re-flash or re-image persistent memory sections or components of their hosts in order to remove persistent memory- based malware. contents.text: Devices with embedded operating systems, such as video gaming consoles and smart home appliances, will most likely be beyond a user's capability to remediate by themselves and could therefore require the aid of vendor-specific advice, updates, and tools. However, in some cases, such devices will have a function or switch to enable the user to reset that device to a factory default configuration, which may sometimes enable the user to remediate the infection. Care should be taken when imparting remediation advice to Internet users given the increasingly wide array of computing devices that can be, or could be, infected by bots in the future.

contents.text: 4. Detection of Bots
contents.ja: ボットの4検出

contents.text: An ISP must first identify that an Internet user is infected or likely to have been infected with a bot (a user is assumed to be their customer or otherwise connected to the ISP's network). The ISP should attempt to detect the presence of bots using methods, processes, and tools that maintain the privacy of the personally identifiable information (PII) of their customers. The ISP should not block legitimate traffic in the course of bot detection and should instead employ detection methods, tools, and processes that seek to be non-disruptive and transparent to Internet users and end user applications.
contents.ja: ISPは、最初のインターネットユーザーは、（ユーザーが自分の顧客またはその他のISPのネットワークに接続されているとする）感染やボットに感染している可能性があることを特定する必要があります。 ISPは、顧客の個人情報（PII）のプライバシーを維持する方法、プロセス、およびツールを使用してボットの存在を検出するために試みるべきです。 ISPは、ボット検出の過程で正規のトラフィックをブロックしてはならないし、代わりにインターネットユーザーおよびエンドユーザーのアプリケーションへの無停止かつ透明であることを目指し検出方法、ツール、およびプロセスを採用する必要があります。

contents.text: Detection methods, tools, and processes may include analysis of specific network and/or application traffic flows (such as traffic to an email server), analysis of aggregate network and/or application traffic data, data feeds received from other ISPs and organizations (such as lists of the ISP's IP addresses that have been reported to have sent spam), feedback from the ISP's customers or other Internet users, as well as a wide variety of other possibilities. In practice, it has proven effective to confirm a bot infection through the use of a combination of multiple bot detection data points. This can help to corroborate information of varying dependability or consistency, as well as to avoid or minimize the possibility of false positive identification of hosts. Detection should also, where possible and feasible, attempt to classify the specific bot infection type in order to confirm that it is malicious in nature, estimate the variety and severity of threats it may pose (such as spam bot, key-logging bot, file distribution bot, etc.), and determine potential methods for eventual remediation. However, given the dynamic nature of botnet management and the criminal incentives to seek quick financial rewards, botnets frequently update or change their core capabilities. As a consequence, botnets that are initially detected and classified by the ISP as made up of one particular type of bot need to be continuously monitored and tracked in order to correctly identify the threat the botnet poses at any particular point in time.
contents.ja: 検出方法、ツール、およびプロセスは、集約ネットワークおよび/またはアプリケーショントラフィックデータの分析（例えば、電子メール・サーバへのトラフィックのように）流れ、特定のネットワーク及び/又はアプリケーション・トラフィックの分析を含むことができる、データは、（例えば、他のISPや組織から受け取ったフィードスパムを送信したことが報告されているISPのIPアドレスのリストなど）、ISPの顧客や他のインターネットユーザーからのフィードバックだけでなく、他の可能性の多種多様。実際には、複数のボット検出データ点の組合せの使用を介してボット感染を確認するのに有効であることが判明しました。これは、様々な信頼性や一貫性の情報を裏付けるために、だけでなく、ホストの偽陽性の識別の可能性を回避または最小限に抑えることができます。検出はまた、可能な場合と可能な、それは自然の中で悪意のあるであることを確認するために、特定のボット感染型を分類しようとすると、このようなスパムボット、キーロギングボット、ファイルとそれがもたらす可能性の脅威（の多様性と重症度を推定しなければなりません配信ボットなど）、および最終的な修復のための潜在的な方法を決定します。しかし、ボットネットの管理と迅速な金融報酬を追求する犯罪者のインセンティブの動的な性質を考えると、ボットネットは頻繁に彼らのコア機能を更新または変更します。その結果、ボットの一つの特定の種類で構成された、最初にISPによって検出および分類されるボットネットは、連続的に正しくボットネットは、時間における任意の特定の時点でポーズの脅威を識別するために監視され、追跡される必要があります。

contents.text: Detection is also time sensitive. If complex analysis is required and multiple confirmations are needed to verify a bot is indeed present, then it is possible that the bot may cause some damage (to either the infected host or a remotely targeted system) before it can be stopped. This means that an ISP needs to balance the desire or need to definitively classify and/or confirm the presence of a bot, which may take an extended period of time, with the ability to predict the likelihood of a bot in a very short period of time. Such determinations must have a relatively low false positive rate in order to maintain the trust of users. This "definitive-versus-likely" challenge is difficult and, when in doubt, ISPs should err on the side of caution by communicating that a bot infection has taken place. This also means that Internet users may benefit from the installation of client-based security software on their host. This can enable rapid heuristically based detection of bot activity, such as the detection of a bot as it starts to communicate with other botnets and execute commands. Any bot detection system should also be capable of adapting, either via manual intervention or automatically, in order to cope with a rapidly evolving threat.
contents.ja: 検出はまた、時間に敏感です。複雑な分析が必要とされ、複数の確認は、ボットが実際に存在であることを確認するために必要とされる場合は、それは停止することができる前に、ボットは、（感染したホストまたはリモート対象システムのどちらかに）いくつかの損傷を引き起こす可能性があります。これは、ISPは、非常に短い期間でボットの可能性を予測する能力を、長い時間がかかる可能性がある、欲求のバランスをとるか、決定的に分類および/またはボットの存在を確認する必要がありますする必要があることを意味します時間。このような決定は、利用者の信頼を維持するために、比較的低い偽陽性率を持っている必要があります。この「決定的な対可能性」の課題は間違いで、ISPがボットに感染が行われたことを伝える、警告の側でエラーに必要がある場合、困難です。また、これは、インターネットユーザーが自分のホスト上のクライアントベースのセキュリティソフトウェアのインストールから利益を得ることができることを意味しています。それは他のボットネットと通信し、コマンドを実行し始めるように、このようなボットの検出としてボット活性の迅速なヒューリスティックベースの検出を可能にすることができます。どれボット検知システムも急速に進化する脅威に対応するためには、手動の介入を介して、または自動のいずれか、適応可能であるべきです。

contents.text: As noted above, detection methods, tools, and processes should ensure that privacy of customers' personally identifiable information (PII) is maintained. This protection afforded to PII should also extend to third parties processing data on behalf of ISPs. While bot detection methods, tools, and processes are similar to spam and virus defenses deployed by the ISP for the benefit of their customers (and may be directly related to those defenses), attempts to detect bots should take into account the need of an ISP to take care to ensure any PII collected or incidentally detected is properly protected. This is important because just as spam defenses may involve scanning the content of email messages, which may contain PII, then so too may bot defenses similarly come into incidental contact with PII. The definition of PII varies from one jurisdiction to the next so proper care should be taken to ensure that any actions taken comply with legislation and good practice in the jurisdiction in which the PII is gathered. Finally, depending upon the geographic region within which an ISP operates, certain methods relating to bot detection may need to be included in relevant terms of service documents or other documents that are available to the customers of a particular ISP.
contents.ja: 上述したように、検出方法、ツール、および方法は、顧客の個人情報（PII）のプライバシーが維持されていることを確認すべきです。 PIIに与えられるこの保護はまたのISPの代わりにデータを処理する第三者に拡張する必要があります。ボット検出方法、ツール、およびプロセスは、（直接それらの防御に関連する可能性がある）、顧客の利益のためにISPによって展開スパムおよびウイルス防御に似ていますが、考慮にISPの必要性を取る必要がありますボットを検出しようすべてのPIIを収集または偶然に検出されたことを確認するために世話をすることは、適切に保護されています。同じように、スパム防御は防御が同様PIIとの偶発的接触するボットもそうあまりにも、その後、PIIを含むことができ、電子メールメッセージの内容をスキャン伴う可能性があるため、これは重要です。 PIIの定義は次のように適切なケアへの1つの管轄から取られた行動はPIIが収集されている管轄で法律やグッドプラクティスに準拠していることを確認するために取られるべきで変わります。最後に、ISPが動作する地理的領域に応じて、ボットの検出に関連する特定の方法は、サービス・ドキュメント、または特定のISPの顧客に利用可能である他のドキュメントの関連用語に含まれる必要があるかもしれません。

contents.text: There are several bot detection methods, tools, and processes that an ISP may choose to utilize, as noted in the list below. It is important to note that the technical solutions available are relatively immature and are likely to change over time, evolving rapidly in the coming years. While these items are described in relation to ISPs, they may also be applicable to organizations operating other networks, such as campus networks and enterprise networks.

contents.text: a. Where it is not legally proscribed and an accepted industry practice in a particular market region, an ISP may in some manner "scan" its IP space in order to detect un-patched or otherwise vulnerable hosts or to detect the signs of infection. This may provide the ISP with the opportunity to easily identify Internet users who appear already to be infected or are at great risk of being infected with a bot. ISPs should note that some types of port scanning may leave network services in a hung state or render them unusable due to common frailties and that many modern firewall and host-based intrusion detection implementations may alert the Internet user to the scan. As a result, the scan may be interpreted as a malicious attack against the host. Vulnerability scanning has a higher probability of leaving accessible network services and applications in a damaged state and will often result in a higher probability of detection by the Internet user and subsequent interpretation as a targeted attack. Depending upon the vulnerability for which an ISP may be scanning, some automated methods of vulnerability checking may result in data being altered or created afresh on the Internet user's host, which can be a problem in many legal environments. It should also be noted that due to the prevalence of Network Address Translation devices, Port Address Translation devices, and/or firewall devices in user networks, network-based vulnerability scanning may be of limited value. Thus, while we note that this is one technique that may be utilized, it is unlikely to be particularly effective and has problematic side effects, which leads the authors to recommend against the use of this particular method.

contents.text: 5.1. Email Notification

contents.text: This is a common form of notification used by ISPs. One drawback of using email is that it is not guaranteed to be viewed within a reasonable time frame, if at all. The user may be using a different primary email address than the one they provided to the ISP. In addition, some ISPs do not provide an email account at all as part of a bundle of Internet services and/or do not have a need for or method by which to request or retain the primary email addresses of Internet users of their networks. Another possibility is that the user, their email client, and/or their email servers could determine or classify such a notification as spam, which could delete the message or otherwise file it in an email folder that the user may not check on a regular and/or timely basis. Bot masters have also been known to impersonate the ISP or trusted sender and send fraudulent emails to the users. This technique of social engineering often leads to new bot infestations. Finally, if the user's email credentials are compromised, then a hacker and/or a bot could simply access the user's email account and delete the email before it is read by the user.

contents.text: 5.2. Telephone Call Notification

contents.text: A telephone call may be an effective means of communication in particularly high-risk situations. However, telephone calls may not be feasible due to the cost of making a large number of calls, as measured in either time, money, organizational resources, server resources, or some other means. In addition, there is no guarantee that the user will answer their phone. To the extent that the telephone number called by the ISP can be answered by the infected computing device, the bot on that host may be able to disconnect, divert, or otherwise interfere with an incoming call. Users may also interpret such a telephone notification as a telemarketing call and therefore not welcome it or not accept the call at all. Finally, even if a representative of the ISP is able to connect with and speak to a user, that user is very likely to lack the necessary technical expertise to understand or be able to effectively deal with the threat.

contents.text: 5.4. Walled Garden Notification

contents.text: Placing a user in a walled garden is another approach that ISPs may take to notify users. A "walled garden" refers to an environment that controls the information and services that a subscriber is allowed to utilize and what network access permissions are granted. A walled garden implementation can range from strict to leaky. In a strict walled garden environment, access to most Internet resources is typically limited by the ISP. In contrast, a leaky walled garden environment permits access to all Internet resources, except those deemed malicious, and ensures access to those that can be used to notify users of infections.
contents.ja: 壁に囲まれた庭園で、ユーザーを配置すると、ISPはユーザーに通知するかかる場合があります別のアプローチです。 「壁に囲まれた庭は、」加入者が利用することを許可され、どのようなネットワークアクセス権限が付与されている情報やサービスを制御した環境を指します。壁に囲まれた庭の実装は厳しいから、漏洩の範囲とすることができます。厳格な壁に囲まれた庭の環境では、ほとんどのインターネットリソースへのアクセスは通常、ISPによって制限されています。これとは対照的に、リーキー壁に囲まれた庭環境では、悪意のあると認められるものを除き、すべてのインターネットリソースへのアクセスを許可し、感染症の利用者に通知するために使用できるものへのアクセスを保証します。

contents.text: Walled gardens are effective because it is possible to notify the user and simultaneously block all communication between the bot and the command and control channel. While in many cases the user is almost guaranteed to view the notification message and take any appropriate remediation actions, this approach can pose other challenges. For example, it is not always the case that a user is actively utilizing a host that implements a web browser, has a web browser actively running on it, or operates another application that uses ports that are redirected to the walled garden. In one example, a user could be playing a game online, via the use of a dedicated, Internet-connected game console. In another example, the user may not be using a host with a web browser when they are placed in the walled garden and may instead be in the course of a telephone conversation or may be expecting to receive a call using a Voice over IP (VoIP) device of some type. As a result, the ISP may feel the need to maintain a potentially lengthy white list of domains that are not subject to the typical restrictions of a walled garden, which could well prove to be an onerous task from an operational perspective.

contents.text: For these reasons, the implementation of a leaky walled garden makes more sense, but a leaky walled garden has a different set of drawbacks. The ISP has to assume that the user will eventually use a web browser to acknowledge the notification; otherwise, the user will remain in the walled garden and not know it. If the intent of the leaky walled garden is solely to notify the user about the bot infection, then the leaky walled garden is not ideal because notification is time sensitive, and the user may not receive the notification until the user invokes a request for the targeted service and/or resource. This means the bot can potentially do more damage. Additionally, the ISP has to identify which services and/or resources to restrict for the purposes of notification. This does not have to be resource specific and can be time based and/or policy based. An example of how notification could be made on a timed basis could involve notification for all HTTP requests every 10 minutes, or show the notification for one in five HTTP requests.

contents.text: The ISP has several options to determine when to let the user out of the walled garden. One approach may be to let the user determine when to exit. Thus, the ISP may also need to support tools to scan the infected host (in the style of a virus scan, rather than a port scan) and determine whether it is still infected or rely on user judgment that the bot has been disabled or removed. One challenge with this approach is that the user might have multiple hosts sharing a single IP address, such as via a common home gateway device that performs Network

contents.text: Finally, when a walled garden is used, a list of well-known addresses for both operating system vendors and security vendors should be created and maintained in a white list that permits access to these sites. contents.text: 5.5. Instant Message Notification
contents.ja: 5.5. インスタントメッセージ通知

contents.text: IM provides the ISP with a simple means to communicate with the user. There are several advantages to using IM that make it an attractive option. If the ISP provides IM service and the user subscribes to it, then the user can be notified easily. IM-based notification can be a cost-effective means to communicate with users automatically from an IM alert system or by a manual process, involving the ISP's support staff. Ideally, the ISP should allow the user to register their IM identity in an ISP account management system and grant permission to be contacted via this means. If the IM service provider supports off-line messaging, then the user can be notified regardless of whether they are currently logged into the IM system.
contents.ja: IMは、ユーザと通信するための簡単な手段をISPが提供されます。その魅力的な選択肢にするIMを使用することにはいくつかの利点があります。 ISPは、IMサービスを提供し、ユーザーがそれに加入している場合、ユーザは簡単に通知することができます。 IMベースの通知は、ISPのサポートスタッフを含む、IM警報システムまたは手動のプロセスによって自動的にユーザと通信するための費用対効果の手段とすることができます。理想的には、ISPは、ユーザーがISPのアカウント管理システムで自分のIMのIDを登録し、この手段を介して接触する許可を与えるようにする必要があります。 IMサービスプロバイダはオフラインメッセージングをサポートしている場合、ユーザは関係なく、彼らは現在、IMシステムにログインしているかどうかの通知を受け取ることができます。

contents.text: There are several drawbacks with this communications method. There is a high probability that a subscriber may interpret the communication to be spim and thus ignore it. Also, not every user uses IM and/or the user may not provide their IM identity to the ISP so some alternative means have to be used. Even in those cases where a user does have an IM address, they may not be signed onto that IM system when the notification is attempted. There may be a privacy concern on the part of users when such an IM notification must be transmitted over a third-party network and/or IM service. As such, should this method be used, the notification should be discreet and not include any PII in the notification itself.
contents.ja: この通信方式にはいくつかの欠点があります。加入者がスピムなるので、それを無視して通信を解釈する確率が高いです。また、必ずしもすべてのユーザーがIMを使用して、および/またはユーザーがISPへのIMのIDを提供することはできませんので、いくつかの代替手段を使用しなければなりません。通知をしようとした場合であっても、ユーザーがIMアドレスを持っているような場合には、彼らはそのIMシステムに署名することはできません。このようIM通知が、サードパーティ製のネットワークおよび/またはIMサービスを介して送信されなければならないユーザーの一部にプライバシーの懸念があるかもしれません。このように、この方法を使用する必要があり、通知は控えめであり、通知自体の任意のPIIを含むべきではありません。

contents.text: 5.6. Short Message Service (SMS) Notification
contents.ja: 5.6. ショートメッセージサービス（SMS）の通知

contents.text: SMS allows the ISP to send a brief description of the problem to notify the user of the issue, typically to a mobile device such as a mobile phone or smart phone. Ideally, the ISP should allow the user to register their mobile number and/or SMS address in an ISP account management system and grant permission to be contacted via this means. The primary advantage of SMS is that users are familiar with receiving text messages and are likely to read them. However, users may not act on the notification immediately if they are not in front of their host at the time of the SMS notification.
contents.ja: SMSは、ISPは、一般的な携帯電話やスマートフォンなどのモバイルデバイスに、問題をユーザに通知するために、問題の簡単な説明を送信することができます。理想的には、ISPは、ユーザーがISPのアカウント管理システムに自分の携帯電話番号および/またはSMSアドレスを登録し、この手段を介して接触する許可を与えるようにする必要があります。 SMSの主な利点は、ユーザーがテキストメッセージを受信に精通していると、それらを読む可能性があるということです。ただし、ユーザーはSMS通知の時にそのホストの前にない場合、直ちに通知に基づいて行動しないことがあります。

contents.text: One disadvantage is that ISPs may have to follow up with an alternate means of notification if not all of the necessary information may be conveyed in one message, given constraints on the number of characters in an individual message (typically 140 characters). Another disadvantage with SMS is the cost associated with it. The ISP has to either build its own SMS gateway to interface with the various wireless network service providers or use a third-party SMS clearinghouse (relay) to notify users. In both cases, an ISP may incur fees related to SMS notifications, depending upon the method used to send the notifications. An additional downside is that SMS messages sent to a user may result in a charge to the user by their wireless provider, depending upon the plan to which they subscribe and the country in which the user resides. Another minor disadvantage is that it is possible to notify the wrong user if the intended user changes their mobile number but forgets to update it with the ISP.
contents.ja: 一つの欠点は、個々のメッセージ（典型的には140文字）の文字の数に制約を与え、ISPはないすべての必要な情報の1つのメッセージで搬送される場合、通知の代替手段をフォローアップしなければならない可能性があることです。 SMSでのもう一つの欠点は、それに関連する費用です。 ISPは、様々な無線ネットワークサービスプロバイダとインターフェースまたはユーザに通知するためにサードパーティのSMSクリアリングハウス（リレー）を使用する独自のSMSゲートウェイを構築することのいずれか有しています。どちらの場合も、ISPは、通知を送信するために使用される方法に応じて、SMS通知に関連する手数料がかかる場合があります。追加の欠点は、ユーザーに送信されたSMSメッセージは、彼らが加入する計画と、ユーザが存在する国によっては、自分のワイヤレスプロバイダにより、ユーザーへの充電をもたらすことができるということです。もう一つのマイナーな欠点は、意図した利用者が自分の携帯電話番号を変更した場合、間違ったことをユーザに通知することが可能であるが、ISPでそれを更新し忘れるということです。

contents.text: There are several other drawbacks with this communications method. There is a high probability that subscriber may interpret the communication to be spam and thus ignore it. Also, not every user uses SMS, and/or the user may not provide their SMS address or mobile number to the ISP. Even in those cases where a user does have an SMS address or mobile number, their device may not be powered on or otherwise available on a wireless network when the notification is attempted. There may also be a privacy concern on the part of users when such an SMS notification must be transmitted over a third-party network and/or SMS clearinghouse. As such, should this method be used, the notification should be discreet and not include any PII in the notification itself.
contents.ja: この通信方式にはいくつかの他の欠点があります。加入者がスパムであるので、それを無視して通信を解釈する確率が高いです。また、必ずしもすべてのユーザーは、SMSを使用し、かつ/またはユーザーがISPへのSMSアドレスや携帯電話番号を提供することはできません。通知が試みられた場合でも、ユーザがSMSアドレスまたはモバイル番号を持っているような場合に、それらのデバイスは、無線ネットワーク上で電源投入またはそうでなければ使用できない場合があります。また、SMS通知が、サードパーティ製のネットワークおよび/またはSMSのクリアリングハウスを介して送信されなければならないユーザーの一部にプライバシーの懸念があるかもしれません。このように、この方法を使用する必要があり、通知は控えめであり、通知自体の任意のPIIを含むべきではありません。

contents.text: 5.7. Web Browser Notification
contents.ja: 5.7.  Webブラウザの通知

contents.text: Near-real-time notification to the user's web browser is another technique that may be utilized for notifying the user [RFC6108], though how such a system might operate is outside the scope of this document. Such a notification could have a comparative advantage over a walled garden notification, in that it does not restrict traffic to a specified list of destinations in the same way that a walled garden would, by definition. However, as with a walled garden notification, there is no guarantee that a user is making use of a web browser at any given time, though such a system could certainly provide a notification when such a browser is eventually used. Compared to a walled garden, a web browser notification is probably preferred from the perspective of Internet users, as it does not have the risk of disrupting non-web sessions, such as online games, VoIP calls, etc. (as noted in Section 5.4).

contents.text: 5.8. Considerations for Notification to Public Network Locations
contents.ja: 5.8. パブリックネットワークの場所への通知のための考慮事項

contents.text: Delivering a notification to a location that provides a shared public network, such as a train station, public square, coffee shop, or similar location may be of low value since the users connecting to such networks are typically highly transient and generally not known to site or network administrators. For example, a system may detect that a host on such a network has a bot, but by the time a notification is generated, that user has departed from the network and moved elsewhere.
contents.ja: このようなネットワークに接続するユーザは、典型的には非常に一過性であり、一般のサイトに知られていないので、そのような駅、公共広場、コーヒーショップのように、共有パブリックネットワークを提供する場所に通知を配信する、または類似の位置が低い値であってもよいですまたはネットワーク管理者。例えば、システムは、ネットワーク上のホストがボットを持っているが、通知が生成される時点で、そのユーザがネットワークから出発し、他の場所に移動したことを検出してもよいです。

contents.text: 5.9. Considerations for Notification to Network Locations Using a Shared IP Address
contents.ja: 5.9. 共有IPアドレスを使用したネットワークの場所への通知のための考慮事項

contents.text: Delivering a notification to a location that accesses the Internet routed through one or more shared public IP addresses may be of low value since it may be quite difficult to differentiate between users when providing a notification. For example, on a business network of 500 users, all sharing one public IP address, it may be sub-optimal to provide a notification to all 500 users if you only need one specific user to be notified and take action. As a result, such networks may find value in establishing a localized bot detection and notification system, just as they are likely to also establish other localized systems for security, file sharing, email, and so on.
contents.ja: 通知を提供する際のユーザーを区別するのは非常に難しいかもしれないので、低い値であってもよい1つ以上の共有パブリックIPアドレスを通じてルーティングされ、インターネットにアクセスした場所に通知をお届けします。たとえば、500人のユーザー、1つのパブリックIPアドレスを共有するすべてのビジネスネットワーク上で、あなただけ通知されるようにある特定のユーザが必要と行動を取る場合は、すべての500人のユーザーへの通知を提供するために、次善のかもしれません。その結果、このようなネットワークは、彼らはまた、その上のセキュリティ、ファイル共有、電子メール、および他のためにローカライズされたシステムを構築する可能性があるのと同様に、ローカライズされたボット検出および通知システムを確立することに価値を見つけることができます。

contents.text: However, should an ISP implement some form of notification to such networks, it may be better to simply send notifications to a designated network administrator at the site. In such a case, the local network administrator may like to receive additional information in such a notification, such as a date and timestamp, the source port of the infected system, and malicious sites and ports that may have been visited.
contents.ja: しかし、ISPは、このようなネットワークへの通知のいくつかのフォームを実装する必要があり、単にサイトで指定されたネットワーク管理者に通知を送信する方が良いかもしれません。そのような場合には、ローカルネットワーク管理者は、日付とタイムスタンプ、感染したシステムの送信元ポート、および訪問されている可能性があり、悪意のあるサイトやポートとして、そのような通知に追加の情報を受信するようなことがあります。

contents.text: 5.10. Notification and End User Expertise
contents.ja: 5.10. 通知とエンドユーザー専門知識

contents.text: The ultimate effectiveness of any of the aforementioned forms of notification is heavily dependent upon both the expertise of the end user and the wording of any such notification. For example, while a user may receive and acknowledge a notification, that user may lack the necessary technical expertise to understand or be able to deal effectively with the threat. As a result, it is important that such notifications use clear and easily understood language, so that the majority of users (who are non-technical) may understand the notification. In addition, a notification should provide easily understood guidance on how to remediate a threat as described in Section 6, potentially with one path for technical users to take and another for non-technical users.

contents.text: 6.2. Professionally Assisted Remediation Process

contents.text: It should be acknowledged that, based on the current state of remediation tools and the technical abilities of end users, that many users may be unable to remediate on their own. This may entail online or telephone assistance for remediation, as well as working face to face with a professional who has training and expertise in the removal of malware. It should be made clear at the time of offering this service that this service is intended for those that do not have the skills or confidence to attempt remediation and is not intended as an up-sell by the ISP.

contents.text: 7. Failure or Refusal to Remediate

contents.text: ISP systems should track the bot infection history of hosts in order to detect when users consistently fail to remediate or refuse to take any steps to remediate. Such steps may include a progression of actions up to and including account termination. Refusal to remediate can be viewed as a business issue, and as such, no technical recommendation is possible.

contents.text: 8. Sharing of Data from the User to the ISP

contents.text: As an additional consideration, it may be useful to create a process by which users could choose, at their option and with their express consent, to share data regarding their bot infections with their ISP and/or another authorized third party. Such third parties may include governmental entities that aggregate threat data, such as the Internet Crime Complaint Center referred to earlier in this document, academic institutions, and/or security researchers. While in many cases the information shared with the user's ISP or designated third parties will only be used for aggregated statistical analysis, it is also possible that certain research needs may be best met with more detailed data. Thus, any such data sharing from a user to the ISP or authorized third party may contain some type of personally identifiable information, either by design or inadvertently. As a result, any such data sharing should be enabled on an opt-in basis, where users review and approve of the data being shared and the parties with which it is to be shared, unless the ISP is already required to share such data in order to comply with local laws and applicable regulations.

contents.text: 9. Security Considerations
contents.ja: 9.セキュリティの考慮事項

contents.text: This document describes in detail the numerous security risks and concerns relating to botnets. As such, it has been appropriate to include specific information about security in each section above. This document describes the security risks related to malicious bot infections themselves, such as enabling identity theft, theft of authentication credentials, and the use of a host to unwittingly participate in a DDoS attack, among many other risks. Finally, the document also describes security risks that may relate to the particular methods of communicating a notification to Internet users. Bot networks and bot infections pose extremely serious security risks, so readers should review this document carefully.
contents.ja: この文書は、詳細にボットネットに関連する多数のセキュリティ上のリスクと懸念を示しています。このように、上記各セクションにおけるセキュリティに関する特定の情報を含むことが適切でした。この文書では、このような無意識のうちに他の多くのリスクの中で、DDoS攻撃に参加する個人情報の盗難、認証資格情報の盗難、およびホストの使用を可能にするなど、悪質なボット感染自体に関連するセキュリティリスクを説明しています。最後に、文書はまた、インターネットユーザーへの通知を通信する特定の方法に関連することができるセキュリティリスクを説明しています。読者は慎重にこの文書を見直す必要がありますので、ボットネットワークとボットの感染は、非常に深刻なセキュリティリスクをもたらします。

contents.text: In addition, regarding notifications as described in Section 5, care should be taken to assure users that notifications have been provided by a trustworthy site and/or party, so that the notification is more difficult for phishers and/or malicious parties using social engineering tactics to mimic. Otherwise, care should be taken to ensure that the user has some level of trust that the notification is valid and/or that the user has some way to verify via some other mechanism or step that the notification is valid.

contents.text: 10. Privacy Considerations
contents.ja: 10.プライバシーに関する注意事項

contents.text: This document describes at a high level the activities to which ISPs should be sensitive, i.e., where the collection or communication of PII may be possible. In addition, when performing notifications to end users (see Section 5), those notifications should not include PII.
contents.ja: この文書では、PIIのコレクション又は通信が可能であるISPは敏感でなければならない活動れるハイレベル、すなわち、に記載されています。また、ユーザーを（セクション5を参照）を終了する通知を行う場合には、これらの通知はPIIを含めるべきではありません。

contents.text: As noted in Section 8, any sharing of data from the user to the ISP and/or authorized third parties should be done on an opt-in basis. Additionally the ISP and or authorized third parties should clearly state what data will be shared and with whom the data will be shared.
contents.ja: 第8章で述べたように、ISP及び/又は承認の第三者へのユーザからのデータの任意の共有はオプトインに基づいて行われるべきです。さらに、ISPおよびまたは認定第三者が明確にデータが共有され、誰とデータが共有されるかを明記してください。

contents.text: Lastly, as noted in other sections, there may be legal requirements in particular legal jurisdictions concerning how long any subscriber-related or other data is retained. An ISP operating in such a jurisdiction should be aware of these requirements and should comply with them.
